title: Tay Forest Park Walks

images.title: Adam Ward / Mighty Douglas Fir
images.caption: Mighty Douglas Fir. Apparently Britains tallest tree at 64.6m or 212ft, a Douglas Fir planted in the 1860's. (Though there seem to be about 4 separate claimants for Britains tallest tree!) Just one of the many fine old Douglas Firs and Larches amongst others at the River Braan near Dunkeld planted by the Dukes of Atholl.

images.title: Lis Burke / March sunshine in Craigvinean Forest
images.caption: March sunshine in Craigvinean Forest. Looking north east along an old boundary wall, which matches up with the 1940s plantation boundary.

images.title: Lis Burke / Creag an Uamhaidh
images.caption: Creag an Uamhaidh. A track skirts the south east slopes of this bare hill top which rises out of Craigvinean Forest.

images.title: Rob Burke / Forest edge
images.caption: Forest edge. At this junction of forest tracks there is a good view north to Ben Vrackie.

images.title: Pine Cone Point by Russel Wills, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Pine Cone Point

images.title: Craigvinean Forest by Russel Wills, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Craigvinean Forest view

description: This circular walk explores the Tay Forest Park near Dunkeld. You can start the walk from The Hermitage Woodland car park. In this area you can enjoy splendid Douglas fir trees, the spectacular Black Linn Falls and views of the River Braan. The route then heads north to explore miles of woodland paths in the Craigvinean Forest. On the way there's pretty forest burns and some splendid viewpoints with views towards nearby Ben Vrackie. Much of the route is also suitable for cyclists. Scroll down for a list of walks in and around the Tay Forest Park.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: The climb to Birnam Hill can be found just south of Dunkeld. There are some excellent views from this fine vantage point. Heading east along the river from the town will take you to the famous Birnam Oak, an ancient tree mentioned in Shakespeare’s Macbeth.

display_address: The Hermitage, A9, Inver, Perth and Kinross, Alba / Scotland, PH8 0JR, United Kingdom
